name: kyanite
description: A small library of pure functional utilities to make life easier and data better

docs.title: compact
docs.desc: Takes an array of items and removes all of the falsy values
examples: compact([1, '', 0, 2]) // => [1, 2]compact([1, '', false, 2, undefined, 3, null]) // => [1, 2, 3]

returns.description: The stripped array

params.description: The array to remove falsy values from
params.name: arr

docs.title: concat
docs.desc: Take an array and concats the values into a new array

returns.description: A newly created array of the concated values

params.description: The array to concat together
params.name: arr

docs.title: concatMap
docs.desc: Take an array and concats the values into a new array after applying the function

returns.description: A newly created array of the concated values

params.description: The function to be applied to each value
params.name: fn

params.description: The array to concat together
params.name: arr

docs.title: difference
docs.desc: Returns an array with the elements present in the first that are not in the second
examples: difference([1, 2, 3], [1]) // => [2, 3]// It's also curriedconst diff = difference([1, 2, 3])diff([1]) // => [2, 3]

returns.description: An array of elements present in the first that are not in the second

params.description: The list to search through
params.name: first

params.description: The second list to compare against
params.name: second

docs.title: drop
docs.desc: Starts at a at desired index and pulls the values from that point until the end

returns.description: An array with the indicated values removed from the array

params.description: The index we want the slice to start at
params.name: i

params.description: The array we want to drop from
params.name: list

docs.title: ensureArray
docs.desc: Ensures that the value passed in is an array, if not it will make it an array orpass back an empty array if the value if undefined/null
examples: ensureArray(1) // => [1]ensureArray() // => []ensureArray(null) // => []ensureArray('test') // => ['test']

returns.description: Returns a new array

params.description: The value to ensure
params.name: x

docs.title: every
docs.desc: Loops through a provided list verifying that every value evaluates to a truthy value.
examples: const data = [1, 2, 3, 4]every(x => x > 0, data) // => trueevery(x => x < 3, data) // => false// It is also curriedconst run = every(x => x > 0)run([1, 2, 3]) // => truerun([-1, 0, 1]) // => false

returns.description: If all values passed will return true else false

params.description: The function to send our values to for validation
params.name: fn

params.description: The list we are to loop through
params.name: x

docs.title: filter
docs.desc: Filter through a filterable data piece using the provided function
examples: const isEven = n => n % 2 === 0filter(isEven, [1, 2, 3, 4]) // => [2, 4]// Is also curriedconst filterer = filter(isEven)filterer([1, 2, 3, 4]) // => [2, 4]

returns.description: Returns a new Array or Object based on the type of list provided

params.description: The predicate function to run on our values
params.name: fn

params.description: The filterable list to go through
params.name: list

docs.title: find
docs.desc: Find an item based on the function sent in and its list
examples: find(v => v.val === 'test', [{val: 'test'}]) // => 'test'find(v => v.val === 'none', [{val: 'test'}, {val: 'none'}]) // => { val: 'none' }find(v => v > 2, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) // => 3// find is also curriedconst finder = find(v => v.val === 'test')finder([{val: 'test'}]) // => 'test'finder([{val: 'test'}, {val: 'none'}]) // => { val: 'test' }

returns.description: Returns either the found item, or false if nothing is found

params.description: The function used/called during the find
params.name: fn

params.description: The list we want to search through
params.name: list

docs.title: findIndex
docs.desc: Runs through an array of values, until it finds the index of one that passes the function, else returns undefined

returns.description: The index the passing value lives at or undefined if it's not found

params.description: The function to test our value against
params.name: fn

params.description: The array to loop through
params.name: list

docs.title: first
docs.desc: Grabs the first index of a passed array or string
examples: const arr = first([1, 3]) // => 1const str = first('abc') // => 'a'

returns.description: Returns whatever was the first piece of our array

params.description: The list or string we want to use
params.name: x

docs.title: groupBy
docs.desc: Groups values of an array based on the function passed in

returns.description: An object with the grouped values

params.description: The function to run our values through
params.name: fn

params.description: The array to go through
params.name: list

docs.title: includes
docs.desc: Checks to see if the provided list contains at at least 1 of the provided value within it
examples: includes(3, [1, 2, 3]) // => true// It is also curriedconst checker = includes(3)checker([1, 2, 3]) // => true

returns.description: A Boolean based on if the value is found or not

params.description: The value we want to search the list for
params.name: a

params.description: The list we want to search through
params.name: list

docs.title: insert
docs.desc: Insert an item in a certain index of an array

returns.description: A new array with the inserted data

params.description: The index number to remove from
params.name: i

params.description: The data we are going to be inserting
params.name: d

params.description: The array to insert into
params.name: arr

docs.title: intersection
docs.desc: Returns an array containing elements present in both arrays
examples: intersection([1, 2, 3, 4], [3, 4, 5, 6]) // => [3, 4]// It's also curriedconst inter = intersection([1, 2, 3, 4])inter([3, 4, 5, 6]) // => [3, 4]

returns.description: A new array containing values that both arrays had

params.description: Our first array value to compare with
params.name: a

params.description: Our second array value to compare with
params.name: b

docs.title: last
docs.desc: Grabs the last index of an array
examples: const arr = last([1, 3]) // => 3const str = last('abc') // => 'c'

returns.description: Returns whatever was the last piece of our array

params.description: The list or string we want to use
params.name: x

docs.title: length
docs.desc: Obtains the length of the passed array

returns.description: The length of the array

params.description: The array to find the length of
params.name: a

docs.title: map
docs.desc: Takes a function and applies it to all of the values within the provided list,and brings back a new list of the same type.
examples: const dbl = n => n * 2map(dbl, [1, 2, 3]) // => [2, 4, 6]// It's also curriedconst dbler = map(dbl)dbler([1, 2, 3]) // => [2, 4, 6]

returns.description: The new Array or Object that was created

params.description: The function to run against the values in our functor
params.name: fn

params.description: The list to iterate through
params.name: list

docs.title: max
docs.desc: Goes through an array of values and grabs the last value of the array when it's been sorted

returns.description: The item that was deemed to be the max

params.description: The Array search through
params.name: list

docs.title: maxBy
docs.desc: Finds the max of an array by applying the provided function to the values provided and reducing it down

returns.description: The item that was deemed to be the max

params.description: The function to apply to each value of the array
params.name: fn

params.description: The Array to search through
params.name: list

docs.title: mean
docs.desc: Get the mean of a set of numbers

returns.description: Returns the mean avg of the numbers

params.description: An amount of numbers to get the mean from
params.name: x

docs.title: min
docs.desc: Goes through an array of values and grabs the first value of the array when it's been sorted

returns.description: Returns the item at the start of an array based on what's passed in

params.description: The Array to sort and grab from
params.name: list

docs.title: minBy
docs.desc: Finds the min of an array by applying the provided function to the values provided and reducing it down

returns.description: The item that was deemed to be the min

params.description: The function to apply to each value of the array
params.name: fn

params.description: The Array to search through
params.name: list

docs.title: nth
docs.desc: Returns the nth element of the given list or string.
examples: nth(3, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]) // => 4// nth is curriedconst third = nth(2)third([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) // => 3

returns.description: Returns the value of the found index

params.description: How much to offset the value
params.name: o

params.description: The Array or list to crawl through
params.name: x

docs.title: partition
docs.desc: Takes a predicate function and a list or filterable data object and returns the pair.One contains the data which passed the predicate function, the other the values that did not.
examples: partition(is(String), ['foo', 'bar', 100]) // => [ ['foo', 'bar'], [100] ]// Is curried as wellconst part = partition(is(String))part(['foo', 'bar', 100]) // => [ ['foo', 'bar'], [100] ]

returns.description: An array containing the first set of elements that passed the predicate function,And a second that did not

params.description: The predicate function to determine which side an element belongs to
params.name: fn

params.description: The list or other filterable to partition through
params.name: list

docs.title: prepend
docs.desc: Returns a new list with the provided value at the front of the given list

returns.description: A new array

params.description: The value we want to put at the front of our list
params.name: x

params.description: The Array or list to prepend to
params.name: list

docs.title: reduce
docs.desc: Accepts an array and runs a reduce based on the passed values

returns.description: Returns based on the original init parameter that is passed in

params.description: The function to run with the reduce
params.name: fn

params.description: The empty initial state of the reduce accumulator
params.name: init

params.description: The list to run our reduce against
params.name: list

docs.title: reject
docs.desc: Filter through a filterable data piece using the provided function returns only those that fail the function test
examples: const isEven = n => n % 2 === 0reject(isEven, [1, 2, 3, 4]) // => [1, 3]// Is also curriedconst rejecter = reject(isEven)rejecter([1, 2, 3, 4]) // => [1, 3]

returns.description: Returns a new Array or Object based on the type of list provided

params.description: The predicate function to run on our values
params.name: fn

params.description: The filterable list to go through
params.name: list

docs.title: remove
docs.desc: Remove an item from a certain point in the index
examples: const test = remove(2, [1, 2, 3, 4]) // => [1, 2, 4]// This is also a curried methodconst remover = remove(2)const test = remover([1, 2, 3, 4]) // => [1, 2, 4]

returns.description: returns the modified array back

params.description: The index number to remove from
params.name: i

params.description: The array in question
params.name: x

docs.title: reverse
docs.desc: Accepts an array and returns a brand new reversed array

returns.description: A new reversed array

params.description: The array to reverse
params.name: arr

docs.title: slice
docs.desc: Returns a subset of an array based on the provided indexes

returns.description: The newly created subset Array

params.description: The index at which to begin extraction
params.name: a

params.description: The index for what the extraction goes to. However does not extract
params.name: b

docs.title: some
docs.desc: Loops through a provided list verifying that at least some values evaluates to a truthy value.
examples: const data = [1, 2, 3, 4]some(x => x > 0, data) // => truesome(x => x < 3) // => truesome(x => x < 0, data) // => false// It is also curriedconst run = some(x => x > 0)run([1, 2, 3]) // => truerun([-1, 0, 1]) // => truerun([-3, -2, -1]) // => false

returns.description: If any values passed will return true else false

params.description: The function to send our values to for validation
params.name: fn

params.description: The list we are to loop through
params.name: x

docs.title: sort
docs.desc: Uses a comparison function to sort an array

returns.description: A new sorted array

params.description: The function used to sort the array
params.name: fn

params.description: The array to be sorted
params.name: a

docs.title: sortBy
docs.desc: Sorts through an array of values using the provided function on each value

returns.description: A newly sorted array

params.description: The function to use on values within our array
params.name: fn

params.description: The array to run through
params.name: list

docs.title: sortWith
docs.desc:
Sorts an array based on the functions passed it, will go through the functions in order
and use ties to the next function in order to break ties
examples:
const data = [{name: 'alice', age: 40}, {name: 'bob', age: 30}, {name: 'clara', age: 40}]
sortWith([
  descendBy(x => x.age),
  ascendBy(x => x.name)
], data) // => [{name: 'alice', age: 40}, {name: 'clara', age: 40}, {name: 'bob', age: 30}]

// It's also curried

const ageNameSort = sortWith([
  descendBy(x => x.age),
  ascendBy(x => x.name)
])

ageNameSort(data) // =>[{name: 'alice', age: 40}, {name: 'clara', age: 40}, {name: 'bob', age: 30}]

returns.description: A new and sorted array

params.description: An array of functions to sort with
params.name: fns

params.description: The array to be sorted
params.name: arr

docs.title: take
docs.desc: Takes the values from an array up until the point specified, then brings those values back

returns.description: A new array of the values taken

params.description: The index we want our take to start at
params.name: i

params.description: The array we are taking from
params.name: list

docs.title: union
docs.desc: Creates a union between two arrays, removing duplicates from each

returns.description: A new array of unique values from each of the passed in arrays

params.description: An array to put through combining
params.name: a

params.description: The rest of the arrays
params.name: rest

docs.title: uniq
docs.desc: Returns an array of unique values from the applied function

returns.description: An array of uniq values from the provided function

params.description: The list to sift through
params.name: list

docs.title: uniqBy
docs.desc: Returns an array of unique values from the applied function

returns.description: An array of unique values from the provided function

params.description: The function to apply
params.name: fn

params.description: The list to sift through
params.name: list

docs.title: update
docs.desc: Add an item to an array within a certain index of the array
examples: update(2, 10, [1, 2, 3]) // => [1, 2, 10]// You can also use it as a curried methodconst updater = update(2, 10)updater([1, 2, 3]) // => [1, 2, 10]// This can be taken further like soconst index = update(2)const val = index(10)val([1, 2, 3]) // => [1, 2, 10]

returns.description: Returns the modified array

params.description: The index number to add at
params.name: index

params.description: What we want to add to our array
params.name: val

params.description: The array in question
params.name: list

docs.title: zip
docs.desc: Takes two arrays and combines them into a key value pair object

returns.description: The combined arrays key value pair

params.description: The array that will act as keys
params.name: x

params.description: The array that will act as values
params.name: y

docs.title: and
docs.desc: Runs an and comparison on the two values passed in
examples:
and(true, true) // => true
and(true, false) // => false
and(false, false) // => false

returns.description: The evaluated outcome of the parameters

params.description: The first boolean to compare
params.name: a

params.description: The second boolean to compare
params.name: b

docs.title: ap
docs.desc: Takes an array of functions to be applied to an array of data, concating the results together

returns.description: A new array of data modified by the functions concated together

params.description: The list of functions to apply
params.name: fns

params.description: The array of data to run the functions on
params.name: list

docs.title: ascend
docs.desc: Determiens which of the two passed in values should be ascended

returns.description: A number based on which value should ascend

params.description: The first value to compare
params.name: a

params.description: The second value to compare
params.name: b

docs.title: ascendBy
docs.desc: Can be used with sort to ascend an array based on the function passed in

returns.description: A number based on where it falls when compared with the other value

params.description: The function to use on values within our array
params.name: fn

params.description: The first value to compare
params.name: a

params.description: The second value to compare
params.name: b

docs.title: both
docs.desc: Validates that the same value passed into two different functions returns truthy for both

returns.description: Based on if both functions return a truthy value when ran

params.description: The first function to test the value in
params.name: f

params.description: The second function to test the value in
params.name: g

params.description: The value to run in the previous two functions
params.name: a

docs.title: branch
docs.desc: Takes 3 functions and a value, and will run either the 2nd or 3rd function based on if the first passes
examples:
branch(
  x => x < 10,
  x => x + 1,
  x => x - 1,
  0
) // => 1

// It's also curried
const b = branch(
  x => x < 10,
  x => x + 1,
  x => x - 1
)

b(0) // => 1
b(12) // => 11

returns.description: The result of the branch function used

params.description: The first function to determine the path of our branch
params.name: p

params.description: The function to run if the first passes
params.name: f

params.description: The function to run if the first fails
params.name: g

params.description: The data to pass long our functions
params.name: a

docs.title: complement
docs.desc: Takes a function and returns a new function that when called returns the opposite truthy/falsy value ofwhat was passed in.
examples: const isNot = complement(is(String))isNot(1) // => trueisNot('test') // => false

returns.description: Returns the opposite function back

params.description: The function we want to apply the complement of
params.name: fn

params.description: The value our functionality is being ran against
params.name: a

docs.title: curry
docs.desc: Create a curried function
examples: const add = curry((a, b) => a + b)add(1)(2) // => 3add(1, 2) // => 3const add1 = add(1)add1(2) // => 3

returns.description: Returns based on the function sent in

params.description: The function we will be running
params.name: f

params.description: extra args to apply if needed
params.name: args

docs.title: curryN
docs.desc: Acts like curry but this one expects you to tell it how many arguments to expectthis allows it to work well with rest parameters and default params.
examples: const add = curryN(2, (a, b) => a + b)add(1)(2) // => 3add(1, 2) // => 3const sum = add(1)sum(2) // => 3sum(4) // => 5const add2 = curryN(2, (a, b = 1) => a + b)const sum1 = add(1)sum1(4) // => 5sum1(undefined) // => 2

returns.description: Returns based on the results of the function passed in

params.description: The number of arguments the function is expecting
params.name: n

params.description: The function we are going to be running with said arguments
params.name: f

params.description: The arguments to apply to said function curry wont execute until this length matches n
params.name: args

docs.title: deepClone
docs.desc: Clones the object sent in (Hard Clone)
examples: const data = { test: 1 }const cloned = deepClone(data) // => { test: 1 }cloned.test = 2console.log(data) // => { test: 1 }console.log(cloned) // => { test: 2 }

returns.description: The newly cloned value

params.description: The value we want to get cloned
params.name: x

docs.title: descend
docs.desc: Determiens which of the two passed in values should be descended

returns.description: A number based on which value should descend

params.description: The first value to compare
params.name: a

params.description: The second value to compare
params.name: b

docs.title: descendBy
docs.desc: Can be used with sort to descend an array based on the function passed in

returns.description: A number based on where it falls when compared with the other value

params.description: The function to use on values within our array
params.name: fn

params.description: The first value to compare
params.name: a

params.description: The second value to compare
params.name: b

docs.title: empty
docs.desc: Empties out the items of the sent value

returns.description: Returns the empty item

params.description: The item to empty
params.name: x

docs.title: encase
docs.desc: Encase the provided function in a try catch which if the function errors will give back an undefined
examples:
encase(x => x.a.b.c, {a: 0}) // => undefined
encase(x => x.a.b.c, {a: {b: {c: 0}}}) // => 0

// It's also curried
const getter = x => x.a.b.c
const en = encase(getter)

en({a: 0}) // => undefined
en(a: {b: {c: 0}}}) // => 0

returns.description: The return of the provided function

params.description: The function to encase before running
params.name: fn

params.description: The value we want to pass into the given function
params.name: a

docs.title: gt
docs.desc: Checks if a value is greater than the other

returns.description: Based on the outcome of the logic a Boolean

params.description: Value to determine if it is greater than the other
params.name: a

params.description: Value to compare to see if it is less than the other
params.name: b

docs.title: gte
docs.desc: Checks if a value is greater than or equal to the other
examples:
gte(2, 1) // => true
gte(1, 1) // => true
gte('b', 'a') // => true

// It's also curried

const g = gte(2)

g(1) // => true
g(2) // => true
g(3) // => false

returns.description: Based on the outcome of the logic a Boolean

params.description: Value to determine if it is greater than or equal to the other
params.name: a

params.description: Value to compare to see if it is less than or equal to the other
params.name: b

docs.title: identical
docs.desc: Performs a check to see if the items are identical in the sense that they reference the same memory
examples: identical(NaN, NaN) // => trueidentical([1], [1]) // => falseconst o = {}identical({}, {}) // => falseidentical(o, o) // => true// Identical is also curriedconst test = identical(NaN)test(NaN) // => true

returns.description: Returns a boolean based on the check

params.description: The first value to compare
params.name: a

params.description: The second value to compare
params.name: b

docs.title: identity
docs.desc: A function that returns the value passed to it
examples: identity(10) // => 10const test = identity(10)console.log(typeof test.constructor) // => 'function'console.log(10.constructor) // => errorfilter(identity, [0, 'cool', null, 1]) // => ['cool', 1]

returns.description: The value

params.description: The value to return
params.name: a

docs.title: is
docs.desc: See if an object is an instance of the supplied constructor, this will also check up the inheritence chain
examples:
is(Object, {}) // => true
is(Array, []) // => true
is(String, '') // => true
is(Number, 0) // => true
is(Boolean, true) // => true
is(Function, a => a) // => true
is(RegExp, /[0-9]/g) // => true

// It is curried as well

const isObject = is(Object)

isObject({}) // => true

// Since almost everything in JS can also be related to an object you will get:
const isObj = is(Object)

isObj({}) // => true
isObj([]) // => true
isObj(function () { }) // => true
isObj(new Boolean(true)) // => true
isObj(new Number(0)) // => true
isObj(/(?:)/) // => true
isObj(1) // => false
isObj('') // => false
isObj(false) // => false

params.description: A Constructor
params.name: Ctor

params.description: The value to test
params.name: x

docs.title: isEmpty
docs.desc: Determines if the entered value is empty or not
examples: isEmpty([]) // => trueisEmpty({}) // => trueisEmpty('') // => trueisEmpty(NaN) // => trueisEmpty(null) // => trueisEmpty(undefined) // => trueisEmpty(true) // => trueisEmpty(false) // => true

returns.description: Returns the boolean after running our check

params.description: Value to check against
params.name: x

docs.title: isEqual
docs.desc: Takes and compares two items. Capable of handling cyclical data structures
examples: const obj = isEqual({}, {}) // => trueconst arr = isEqual([], []) // => true

returns.description: Returns the boolean after running our comparison check

params.description: First item to compare
params.name: a

params.description: Second item to compare
params.name: b

docs.title: isNil
docs.desc: Checks if the value is a null value
examples: isNill(null) // => trueisNill() // => trueisNill(1) // => false

returns.description: Returns a boolean based on the check

params.description: The value to run our test against
params.name: x

docs.title: juxt
docs.desc: Applies the provided function and turns them into a single function you can use on a value
examples: const getRange = juxt([Math.min, Math.max])getRange(3, 4, 9, -3) // => [-3, 9]

returns.description: The function you can use on your data value

params.description: An array of functions to apply
params.name: fns

docs.title: lt
docs.desc: Checks if a value is less than the other
examples:
lt(1, 2) // => true
lt('a', 'b') // => true

// It's also curried

const g = lt(2)

g(1) // => false
g(2) // => false
g(3) // => true

returns.description: Based on the outcome of the logic a Boolean

params.description: Value to determine if it is greater than the other
params.name: a

params.description: Value to compare to see if it is less than the other
params.name: b

docs.title: lte
docs.desc: Checks if a value is less than or equal to the other
examples:
lte(1, 2) // => true
lte(1, 1) // => true
lte('a', 'b') // => true

// It's also curried

const g = lte(2)

g(1) // => false
g(2) // => true
g(3) // => true

returns.description: Based on the outcome of the logic a Boolean

params.description: Value to determine if it is greater than or equal to the other
params.name: a

params.description: Value to compare to see if it is less than or equal to the other
params.name: b

docs.title: not
docs.desc: Returns boolean based on if the value is not
examples: const reverse = not(true) // => false

returns.description: Returns boolean back based on the results

params.description: The values to compare against
params.name: x

docs.title: on
docs.desc: Applies the second function to the values passed in, and then runs the first function against those new values

returns.description: A value based on the first functions return

params.description: The first function being ran against the values from the second
params.name: fn

params.description: The function to be applied to the two values passed in
params.name: gn

params.description: The first value to use
params.name: a

params.description: The second value we want to use
params.name: b

docs.title: or
docs.desc: Runs an or comparison on the two values passed in
examples:
or(true, true) // => true
or(true, false) // => true
or(false, false) // => false

returns.description: The evaluated outcome of the parameters

params.description: The first boolean to compare
params.name: a

params.description: The second boolean to compare
params.name: b

docs.title: pipe
docs.desc: Applies a sequence of transformations over a value.
examples: pipe([add(2), mul(2)], 10) // => 24// It's also curriedconst piper = pipe([add(2), mul(2)])piper(10) // => 24

returns.description: The transformed value

params.description: The array of functions to apply to our value
params.name: list

params.description: The value to apply our functions too
params.name: a

docs.title: range
docs.desc: Create an array range from start to end
examples: range(3, 7) // => [3, 4, 5, 6]range(3) // => [0, 1, 2]range() // => []range(NaN) // => TypeError: Arguments should be Numbers

returns.description: Returns an array of numbers consisting of the range

params.description: Starting number for the range
params.name: from

params.description: Number to end on for the range
params.name: to

docs.title: type
docs.desc: Finds the type of the sent value
examples: type({}) // => 'Object'type([]) // => 'Array'type(null) // => 'Null'type(undefined) // => 'Undefined'type('hi') // => 'String'type(1) // => 'Number'type(/1/g) // => 'RegExp'type(new Date()) // => 'Date'type(true) // => 'Boolean'

returns.description: A string based on the type of the value passed in

params.description: The value to test
params.name: x

docs.title: when
docs.desc: Takes a value and if it passes the check function (1st param) then it will apply the action function (2nd param) otherwise undefined is given back

returns.description: Returns whatever the action function returns, or undefined

params.description: The check function that when passed if returns a truthy value trigger the action
params.name: fn

params.description: The action function which is fired when the logic passes
params.name: act

params.description: The arguments to pass to both functions
params.name: args

docs.title: add
docs.desc: Adds the provided items together
examples: add(1, 2) // => 3// It's also curriedconst adder = add(2)adder(3) // => 5adder(2) // => 4

returns.description: The sum of the numbers

params.description: The first number to add
params.name: a

params.description: The second number to add
params.name: b

docs.title: between
docs.desc: Checks to see if a number is between two other provided numbers

returns.description: Whether or not the provided number is between the other two numbers

params.description: The number our value should be greater than or equal too
params.name: a

params.description: The number our value should be less than or equal too
params.name: b

params.description: The value to compare with
params.name: n

docs.title: div
docs.desc: Divides the provided items
examples: div(2, 1) // => 2// It's also curriedconst divide = div(15)divide(3) // => 5divide(5) // => 3

returns.description: The quotient of the two numbers

params.description: The divisor which the dividend will be divided by
params.name: a

params.description: The dividend of the division problem
params.name: b

docs.title: factors
docs.desc: Takes a number and builds an array of factors for that number

returns.description: A new array which will contain the valid factors of the given number

params.description: The number it should find the factors of
params.name: x

docs.title: gcd
docs.desc: Determines the greatest common denominator of the numbers passed in

returns.description: The Greatest Common Denominator

params.description: The First number to use
params.name: a

params.description: The Second number to use
params.name: b

docs.title: isEven
docs.desc: Checks if the provided number is even or not
examples:
isEven(2) // => true
isEven(12) // => true
isEven(1) // => false
isEven(NaN) // => false

returns.description: Whether or not the provided number is even

params.description: The number to check if its even
params.name: n

docs.title: isOdd
docs.desc: Checks if the provided number is odd or not
examples:
isOdd(2) // => false
isOdd(NaN) // => false
isOdd(1) // => true
isOdd(3) // => true

returns.description: Whether or not the number is odd

params.description: The number to check against
params.name: n

docs.title: isPrime
docs.desc: Determines if the number passed in is a prime number or not
examples:
isPrime(5) // => true
isPrime(5009) // => true
isPrime(6) // => false
isPrime(5010) // => false

returns.description: A boolean based on if the number is prime

params.description: The number to check if its prime or not
params.name: x

docs.title: lcm
docs.desc: Finds the least common multiple of the provided numbers

returns.description: The least common multiple of the two numbers

params.description: The first number to use
params.name: a

params.description: The second number to use
params.name: b

docs.title: mul
docs.desc: Multiplies the provided items
examples: mul(2, 1) // => 2// It's also curriedconst multiply = mul(5)multiply(3) // => 15multiply(2) // => 10

returns.description: The product of the numbers

params.description: The first factor to multiply with
params.name: a

params.description: The second factor to multiply with
params.name: b

docs.title: pow
docs.desc: Take a base number and brings it to the value of base^exponent

returns.description: A number representing the given base taken to the power of the given exponent

params.description: The exponent used to raise the base number
params.name: a

params.description: The base Number
params.name: b

docs.title: rem
docs.desc: Takes two numbers and gets the remainder from the division

returns.description: The remainder of the two numbers

params.description: The dividend of the division problem
params.name: a

params.description: The divisor which the dividend will be divided by
params.name: b

docs.title: round
docs.desc: Round a number using exponent rounding

returns.description: The rounded number to the desired precision

params.description: The precision we want the number to be rounded to
params.name: precision

params.description: The number we are going to round
params.name: num

docs.title: sub
docs.desc: Subtracts the provided items
examples: sub(2, 1) // => 1// It's also curriedconst subtract = sub(5)subtract(3) // => 2subtract(2) // => 3

returns.description: The difference of the numbers

params.description: The number to subtract from
params.name: a

params.description: The number to subtract with
params.name: b

docs.title: any
docs.desc: Works a lot like every for array, but for the object data type. Returns whether every key matches the predicate or not
examples: const run = any({ a: x => x === 'foo', b: x => x !== 'bar'})run({ a: 'foo', b: 'xxx', x: 11, y: 19 }) // => truerun({ a: 'xxx', b: 'bar' }) // => false

returns.description: A boolean dependent on whether or not any values passed

params.description: An Object schema containing the matching properties and the function to run
params.name: schema

params.description: The object to run through
params.name: obj

docs.title: assign
docs.desc: Create a new object from the provided objects in the parameters defaults to Object.assign if able

returns.description: A new Object

params.description: The object(s) we want to combine
params.name: args

docs.title: clone
docs.desc: Creates either a shallow or deep clone of the provided object

returns.description: A clone of the provided object

params.description: The object we want to create a clone of
params.name: x

params.description: Whether or not we want to create a shallow or deep clone of the object
params.name: deep

docs.title: compress
docs.desc: Takes an object and compresses it down removing undefined or null values
examples: compress({ thing: '', test: 1, other: undefined }) // => { thing: '', test: 1 }compress({ thing: '', test: 1, other: null }) // => { thing: '', test: 1 }

returns.description: Returns a new object without the unwanted values

params.description: The Object to compress
params.name: obj

docs.title: defaults
docs.desc: Applies default properties to an object that does not contain the smae or contains falsey values on those properties
examples: defaults({ test: 1, thing: 2 }, { thing: 4 }) // => { test: 1, thing: 4 }// It's also curriedconst def = defaults({ test: 1, thing: 2 })def({ thing: 4 }) // => { test: 1, thing: 4 }

returns.description: A New object

params.description: The default object to reference
params.name: def

params.description: The data object to loop through
params.name: data

docs.title: draft
docs.desc: Runs a provided function against all of the values that are within the provided object

returns.description: A new object with the updated data from our applied function

params.description: The Function we want to apply to all of the data values
params.name: fn

params.description: The object to apply our functions too
params.name: obj

docs.title: entries
docs.desc: Creates an array of arrays with the key value pairs of an object

returns.description: An array of arrays with the key value pairs from the object

params.description: The object we want to grab our data from
params.name: obj

docs.title: has
docs.desc: Determines if the object has a property
examples: const obj = has('thing', { test: 1, thing: 2 }) // => true// has is also curriedconst propSet = has('thing')propSet({ test: 1, thing: 2 }) // => true

returns.description: Returns based on if the prop is found or not

params.description: The prop to look for
params.name: prop

params.description: The Object we are searching
params.name: obj

docs.title: head
docs.desc: Returns the first value from an object

returns.description: The first value within the object

params.description: The object to retrieve the value from
params.name: obj

docs.title: height
docs.desc: Works a lot like length for arrays, but allows you to get the length of an object

returns.description: The length of the object

params.description: The object we want to read the length of
params.name: obj

docs.title: omit
docs.desc: Create a new Array/Object by omitting the requested values
examples: const obj = omit('test', { test: '3432', thing: 123 }) // => { thing: 123 }const arr = omit(['a', 'b'], { a: 1, b: 2, c: 3}) // => { c: 3 }// omit is curriedconst omitKeys = omit('test')omitKeys({ test: '3432', thing: 123 }) // => { thing: 123 }

returns.description: Returns the newly created data without the omitted values

params.description: The key(s) in which to omit from the data
params.name: key

params.description: The object to search through and filter
params.name: x

docs.title: path
docs.desc: Find an item based on the function sent in and its list

returns.description: Returns Maybe Data if found, undefined if not

params.description: The path to safely traverse the object with
params.name: keys

params.description: The object to traverse
params.name: obj

docs.title: plan
docs.desc: Uses a schema to allow you to plan out functions being ran against values within your object

returns.description: A new object with the updated data from our applied functions

params.description: The object of functions we want to apply
params.name: schema

params.description: The object to apply our functions too
params.name: obj

docs.title: pluck
docs.desc: Recursively digs through objects to create a new list of values based on the provided property name and provided object

returns.description: The new list which will be the same type as the list provided

params.description: The property to look for
params.name: p

params.description: An array of objects or a single object to pluck through
params.name: list

docs.title: prop
docs.desc: Brings back the indicated property of an object if it exists
examples: prop('thing', { thing: 'test' }) // => 'test'prop('thing', {}) // => undefinedmap(prop('a'), [{ a: 1 }, { a: 2 }, { a: 3 }]) // => [1, 2, 3]// It is also curriedconst proper = prop('a')proper({ a: 1, b: 2 }) // => 1

returns.description: The value that exists at 'obj.p'

params.description: The array path of the property we are looking for
params.name: p

params.description: The object to search through
params.name: obj

docs.title: props
docs.desc: Pulls a list of values from an object and returns them as an array

returns.description: An array of values pulled from the object

params.description: The list of properties to get values from
params.name: keys

params.description: The object to map through
params.name: obj

docs.title: sift
docs.desc: Works a lot like an array filter, but for the object data typeAccepts a function and an object, it then runs the function against each value
examples: sift(x => typeof x === 'string', {  id: 44,  thing: 'test',  other: 'cool'}) // => { thing: 'test', other: 'cool' }// It's also curriedconst sifter = sift(x => typeof x === 'string')sifter({ id: 44, thing: 'test', other: 'cool' }) // => { thing: 'test', other: 'cool' }

returns.description: A new filtered out object

params.description: A function to run against the values within the object
params.name: fn

params.description: The object to sift through
params.name: obj

docs.title: tail
docs.desc: Returns the last value from an object

returns.description: The last value within the object

params.description: The object to retrieve the value from
params.name: obj

docs.title: unzip
docs.desc: Takes an object and breaks it down into two arrays one being the keys, the other being the values

returns.description: An array of 2 arrays, the first being an array of keys, the second being an array of values

params.description: The object we want to unzip into arrays
params.name: obj

docs.title: values
docs.desc: Grabs the values from a key value pair object

returns.description: An array of values from the object

params.description: The object we want to grab our values from
params.name: obj

docs.title: whole
docs.desc: Works a lot like every for array, but for the object data type. Returns whether every key matches the predicate or not
examples: const run = whole({ a: x => x === 'foo', b: x => x !== 'bar', x: x => x > 10, y: x => x < 20 })run({ a: 'foo', b: 'xxx', x: 11, y: 19 }) // => truerun({ a: 'xxx', b: 'xxx', x: 11, y: 19 }) // => false

returns.description: A boolean dependent on whether or not all values passed

params.description: An Object schema containing the matching properties and the function to run
params.name: schema

params.description: The object to sift through
params.name: obj

docs.title: capitalize
docs.desc: Capitalizes the first letter of a string
examples: capitalize('test') // => 'Test'capitalize('small brown cow') // => 'Small brown cow'

returns.description: The capitalized string

params.description: The string we want to capitalize
params.name: str

docs.title: contains
docs.desc: Goes through a provided string and attempts to find the provided value within it
examples: contains('cow', 'small brown cow') // => truecontains('cow', 'Small Brown Cow') // => trueconst x = 'cow'contains('cow', `small brown ${x}`) // => true// It's also curriedconst checker = contains('cow')checker('small brown cow') // => true

returns.description: Based on if the string is found or not

params.description: The string we want to search through
params.name: str

params.description: The string we want to find
params.name: a

docs.title: fuzzySearch
docs.desc: Fuzzy search setup to look find things fast and effective

returns.description: Returns a boolean determined by if the value is found or not by the search

params.description: The Item to search
params.name: needle

params.description: The value to search for
params.name: haystack

docs.title: join
docs.desc: Joins together an array of strings with whatever string was passed in

returns.description: The joined string

params.description: The string we want to use for the join
params.name: str

params.description: The array to join
params.name: list

docs.title: strip
docs.desc: Accepts a string value and removes all whitespace from it
examples: strip('I am squished') // => 'Iamsquished'

returns.description: The stripped string

params.description: The string to strip down
params.name: a

docs.title: toLower
docs.desc: Transform a provided string into an lowercase version
examples:
toLower('HI') // => 'hi'
toLower('TEST.123.HELLO') // => 'test.123.hello'

returns.description: The string in lower case format

params.description: The string to lower case
params.name: a

docs.title: toUpper
docs.desc: Transform a provided string into an uppercase version
examples:
toUpper('hi') // => 'HI'
toUpper('test.123.hello') // => 'TEST.123.HELLO'

returns.description: The string in upper case format

params.description: The string to upper case
params.name: a

docs.title: trim
docs.desc: Accepts a string value and trims it's white space
examples: trim('my new cow   ') // => 'my new cow'trim('   new things   ') // => 'new things'

returns.description: The trimmed string

params.description: The string to trim
params.name: str

docs.title: words
docs.desc: Takes a string and breaks the words down into an array
examples: words('my brown cow') // => ['my', 'brown', 'cow']

returns.description: The words broken down into an array of strings

params.description: The string we want to break down
params.name: str
